title: Arrow’s Impossibility Theorem (1951)
formal_statement: For three or more alternatives, no Social Welfare Function (SWF) mapping unrestricted individual weak orderings to a complete and transitive social ranking can satisfy Pareto efficiency, Independence of Irrelevant Alternatives (IIA), and Non-dictatorship simultaneously.
plain_language: With at least three choices, you cannot rank options for a group in a way that always respects unanimous improvements, ignores irrelevant options, and avoids dictatorship—unless you restrict the kinds of preferences or drop an axiom.
assumptions_scope: Individuals have complete and transitive preferences (weak orders)
SWF returns a complete and transitive social ranking
Preference domain is unrestricted (all weak orderings allowed)
typical_traps: Confusing choice rules (pick a winner) with social welfare functions (return a full ranking).
Assuming majority rule rankings are always transitive.
Overlooking domain restrictions (e.g., single-peaked) that evade the impossibility.

escape_hatches.description: Limit preferences to single-peaked on a line; median voter and certain aggregation rules yield transitive social rankings.
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Assumption may be unrealistic in many settings.

escape_hatches.description: Switch from SWF to a Social Choice Function (SCF) that selects a winner; some SCFs satisfy analogues under weaker conditions.
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Does not provide a complete social ranking.

escape_hatches.description: Allow small probability of violating IIA or Pareto or accept approximate transitivity.
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Axioms no longer hold exactly; interpretation depends on tolerance.

test_or_check: Verify the setting has ≥3 alternatives, unrestricted domain, and requires an SWF. If all Arrow axioms are claimed, construct or search for a preference profile (e.g., Condorcet cycle) to refute transitivity or diagnose which axiom is violated.
references: Arrow, K. J. (1951). Social Choice and Individual Values. Wiley.

references.citation: Sen, A. (1970). Collective Choice and Social Welfare. Holden-Day.

assumptions.text: Individual preferences are weak orders (complete and transitive).

bridges.note: Both illustrate constraints on aggregation without dictatorship.
